text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Teachers in Tallinn gathered yesterday to discuss a strike if they do not receive a 14 percent pay hike before May 1.
- The government discussed tighter regulations for service cars.
- At a farewell meeting of the former city government in Tartu, ex- mayor Tonis Lukas said that Pro Patria politicians would return to the power.
- Estonian universities should have the right to determine education fees for foreign students themselves, the rector of Tartu University said at a meeting with the Education Ministry leaders.
- The largest passenger ferry in Estonian shipping begins a Helsinki- Tallinn route today. The vessel can carry 450 cars and 1,700 people.
- The finance ministry may ask the government to increase the period for using privatisation vouchers until December 31, 2000, Finance Minister Mart Opmann said. Currently the period ends in 1998.
- Thieves broke into Valga Orthodox church in April and stole 70 ancient icons worth an estimated one million kroons, police said.
- Meat manufacturers predict a 15-20 percent rise in their produce if protective tariffs are imposed for imported pork, Peeter Maspanov, chairman of the Meat Producers Union, said.
- Priit Saksing, director of the metal plant SILMET, was yesterday elected chairman of the Sillamae city council.
- The Rural Bank, looking for new investment areas, will soon sign a cooperation agreement with Torva city, South Estonia, for investing 100 million kroons in the region.
